36528777.review:
I'm somehow a lot better at this game after drinking a big cup of bitter hot chocolate.

This game was made by the same guy who made UBERMOSH, so I'm going to compare some aspects of this game to that since that's his only other game that I've played.

SWARMRIDERS is a fairly difficult game, although somehow I find it somewhat easier than UBERMOSH. It's got nicer art, and a nicer soundtrack than UBERMOSH as well. You don't have to click any buttons to shoot, you're always shooting, and I think that's part of what makes it easier than UBERMOSH--one less thing to worry about. SWARMRIDERS also has better indication of when you're about to be extracted from the game, instead of having a respawn counter in the upper left corner of the screen, you have a health percentage counter that's surrounding the motorcycle you're on, and changes colour from yellow to red once you've hit 25% (or possibly 20%, 15% or 10%. I'm not sure because the game goes so fast that I'm usually dead very soon after I hit that point). One thing I don't like about this game is how big the smoke clouds that come from the things you're shooting. (I don't know what they're called or if they have a name)

This honestly seems like the type of game I'd expect to see in an arcade. If I had the skills I'd throw together a design for an arcade cabinet for this game just for the hell of it.

34913764.review:
画面左端から追いすがってくる変なモノからひたすら逃げ続ける疾走ゲーです。

自機は2人乗りのバイクのようなサンドバギーのような何かで、動画を観ての通り常にフルスロットルです。
後ろにタンデムしている相棒も、マシンガンのトリガーは常に引きっぱなしです。
たいへんロックでよろしいと思います。

ゲームとしては、
「敵に向かって進んでいかない後ろ向きなSTG」
というか
「ベルトスクロールアクションの、後ろから敵が追ってくるステージのアレ」
というか、そんな感じです。

自機と火器の操作を同時に行えるので、単調なようでいてけっこう忙しくて楽しいです。
追ってくる敵の何体かは画面の外側から先回りしてこようとしてくるので、真後ろから追ってくる一団をいかに手早く処理してそれらに対処できるかが鍵っぽいです。
あと、マシンガンはいかにも揺れる車上でデタラメに掃射している感があって、適当にワイパーしているとかなり撃ち漏らしが出ます。射線を固定して自機のほうを動かしてやるとイイ感じに掃射できるかも？

無料ゲーなりの大雑把な作りが却って雰囲気づくりに一役買ってる感じで、
「お、この雰囲気わりと好きだな」
と動画を観て感じた人には手放しでおススメです。

34701549.review:
I would say that Swarmriders is the most enjoyable concept thus far from Walter and, with a bit of work, could be turned into a high quality game. For now, it's a bit short and plays far more like a proof of concept than an actual game, lasting a total of ~5 minutes for 100% completion if you get the hang of it fairly quickly.

One major improvement compared to the Ubermosh series is that it plays far more "fairly." Whereas Ubermosh likes to spawn enemies above and below you in a way that's hard to react to, this game warns you far in advance of the challenges you're about to face. The controls are also responsive, but it's easy to get lost in all the explosions and forget exactly where you're firing in some cases, just like in Ubermosh. It may only be a difference of a centimeter, but it's enough to make the difference between clearing the screen and being swarmed.

One of my biggest complaints is one I have with all of Walter's games here on Steam, and it's that most of the games don't really go anywhere. They don't develop. They're short, somewhat one dimensional arcade experiences that are more or less predictable. If more time was spent creating a deeper game, perhaps with levels or something at least, the quality would improve dramatically as the structure is already mostly solid.

31837251.review:
SWARMRIDERS developed by Walter Machado and Released on the PC platform on: Jun 15, 2016. As of this writing, there is no user feedback/review on Metacritic (http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/swarmriders).

[quote=Walter Machado]
SWARMRIDERS is a FREE "endless runner"+"twin stick shooter" ARCADE mashup. A "machine gun swarm surfing minigame" made as a bonus content for the UBERMOSH community...Players can expect a few minutes of elegant gameplay, responsive controls and a heart pumping original soundtrack. [/quote] 

[i]"Players can [u]expect[/u] a few minutes of [u]elegant gameplay[/u], [u]responsive controls[/u] and a heart pumping original soundtrack."[/I] 

Oh, REALLY?! *Turns green* Rips my own hair out & F$#king smash my pc to bits and pound the earth until it cracks into the core and explode from the milky way system.. This ain't another one of my 'brutal honest mode review' but it could've easily been one. 

*Bites a mouth piece, with red eyes and continues to write*

What is it about?
As the product description says, SWARMRIDERS (SR) is an endless runner, a shoot em up arcade type of game. You control a bike with 2 person; 1 rider and a 'gunner'. Your goal is to survive as long as you possible can from the swarm (of aliens?)

The Controls, Visuals
Very simple controls. Standard WSAD keyboard and mouse. It supports controller too.
Visually, the entire theme is set in a dark world kinda-feel. So it's dark. The only colors you'll be seeing is white, red stripes from these aliens? (I don't know what to call these because I don't play UBERMOSH) and purple rays from your gunner. And a tiny yellow wording below the bike to show your bike's life. The rest? BLACK. and, and The game engine seems to be running on DOS engine like meaning to say there's PIXELS! 


My personal thoughts
How bad can this get right? You just control a bike and shoot off swarm of aliens.

After 20 minutes of gameplay. Switches off the speaker. The Heart pumping soundtrack is killing me.

There is no level progression. There is no weapon/bike/anything to upgrade! There is no story There is nothing! You only control the bike, you shoot off all this freaking aliens swarming on your screen and hope to survive until 1 min 50 sec to obtain 100% achievement and uninstall this product. It's that Simple & Honest. Because there is nothing to keep consumer engage to this product. 2 minute tops product shelf life. 

The way I am playing this game is no way near what the product describes: ELEGANT.
I am like a mad man moving my mouse like a maniac. To the point my whole PC table is trembling. FPS RTS RPG RACING games HORROR GAMES SIM GAMES - I've never played until my whole PC TABLE IS ROCKING BUT THIS PRODUCT MADE ME DO SO! ELEGANT?! *vomits more blood*

Don't talk to me about responsive control when I am literally moving the mouse like a maniac. 
Ok, controls are working beautifully. No bugs. No glitches. For this, I'll give SR the deserving credit. 60 FPS and my mouse is responsive -my screen is filled with purple lasers- 

Now for the rant. 2 things puzzles me..and disappointed me greatly.
[olist]
    [*]Aliens attacking you from outside the view?!
    [*]Alien explodes on death and releases a FREAKING GIANT PIXELLATE CLOUD?!
[/olist] 

I have to ask. Was this design choice intentional? Was it to give players challenge? Was this the best thing the dev could think of? 

From the aspect of Design, I am really disappointed. How could you design enemies that attack players outside of the view? That's cheap and unfair - the aliens come in hordes of and they can even outrun your bike. So why is it that you allow them to attack players from top and bottom out-of-the-screen? which is why if you take a look at some of the feedbacks, people are saying this game is more of a luck rather than skill. 

On top of that, the aliens explodes on death and release this crazy epic huge smoke (PIXELS!) FOG of WAR that blocks the user view to be able to see how many more swarm are coming. By the time the fog starts to dissipates, it would be too late to dodge.


As a dev, if this is the best you can think of to provide "challenge" to your consumer? You may not realize it but you are shooting yourself in the foot with this 2 design choice. I, for one will remember the horrible experience and I will make sure not to invest in any future product developed by you. I am sorry but take look at steam. There are TONS of indie games. (Some are horrible BUT) There are better product out there with better gameplay, engagement and more fun as compared to SR. What reasons should I support you after experiencing such a negative gameplay experience ?

Now, the next thing I am disappointed is at the steam community who supports this product. While It may be unfair to say so because everyone has different preference but coming from the 2 design issue: it seems the community is open to accepting games that makes enemy attack players outside of the view/fov? This is a dangerous sign. If other developer picks up this idea and start giving us this sort of game..are you really going to support them? Do you really want to see more of this kind of game? 

If you answered yes - okay, fine. At least you are aware about the consequences [u][b]BUT[/b][/u] 
If you answered NO - then please stop supporting/up voting this sort of games. Stop saying negative/funny description and still upvoting this sort of game. Once the trend picks up, It's hard to hold them back. Look at CS, Dota, king of hills, smite? look at how many variants has appeared?!  

My Summary
Do I want to see another similar product on steam? Do I want to go through this sort of gameplay experience? The answer is a simple [b][u]NO[/u][/b]. I don't care if a game is FREE or cost me $200. If it has issues, it has issues. A free game does not give warrant itself "to have issues". If that's the sort of mentality people are having - then you should be in "open beta"/"alpha" games where you can feast on ALLLLL the issues you want.

So, on the scale of 0 - 10, my personal rating for SWARMRIDERS is an [b]EPIC ELEGANT[/b] score worth 4/10.

*Gets down from the bike. Take me aliens. Take me now & End my misery so I can stop rocking my god damn table*

29026668.review: It's free. It's simple. It works (it hasn't crashed or frozen on me). It has 4 achievements. Objective is simply to survive as long as you can while constantly auto-shooting & avoiding swarms of incoming enemies. It has no configurable options/settings, but doesn't really need many. 28963333.review:
Kostenlos + Achievements. Schon mal positiv zu erwähnen.

Spielprinzip: An sich simpel, aber auf der anderen Seite auch nicht. Man muss Gegner im automatischen Dauerfeuer abknallen, die Schaden zufügen, wenn Sie dich berühren. Klingt fast noch einfach, wenn es nicht wirklich unglaubliche viele, gleichzeitig und von allen Seiten wären. Man muss so lange wie möglich "überleben". Wenn man ein absoluter Nerd ist und Talent für solche Spiele besitzt und einfach eine sehr gute Übersicht, Reflexe und Koordination gleichzeitig besitzt, kann das Spiel theoretisch in 2,5 Minuten zu 100% durchspielen. Klingt wenig, kommt einem aber unendlich vor, wenn man es selber versucht.
Ich habe "nur" etwas über 30 Minuten gebraucht und sogar fast 3,5 Minuten geschafft, was aber wohl auch echt glücklich war. Die ersten ~ 20 Minuten habe ich es nicht mal über 60 Sekunden geschafft! 
Aber das Schöne ist, dass man in dem Spiel einfach schnell besser werden kann, wenn man sich richtig konzentriert :)

Abzüge gibts aus meienr Sicht dafür, dass es keine Healthbar gibt und man auch nicht wirklich gut merkt, wenn man Schaden nimmt - man weiß nur, dass man nur noch 1 einzigen Hit nehmen darf, wenn die Farbe von gelb auf rot wechselt - also wenn es quasi schon fast zu spät ist.. :-/

8/10

26029893.review:
L’économie n’est pas que l’activité par laquelle Goldman Sachs l’a mise profond à un microcosme qui l’a lui-même mise tout aussi profond à Jérôme Kerviel, c’est aussi l’art de faire beaucoup avec peu. En cela, le Nobel n’est pas loin pour Walter Machado.

Avec un concept d’endless runner simplissime, deux pauvres modèles 2D et un dessin sombre et fascinant qui nous accroche à son écran titre, SWARMRIDERS contient un ratio record d’émotions par octet. L’oeil lancé beaucoup plus loin que les seules limites du moniteur, occupé à projeter sur les murs de la chambre des scènes d’apocalypse et des histoires de fin du monde, le joueur s’invente les préliminaires de ce qui sera une courte mais très intense Fury Road. Et puis il appuie sur la touche [i]Entrée[/i].

Difficile et survolté, SWARMRIDERS ne nous lasse pas de nos échecs grâce à une bande sonore si virile qu'elle donne envie de changer de coiffure pour une crête iroquoise très haute, de descendre dans la rue taper sur du punk, se cogner soi-même ou essayer de s'immoler soi et les autres par la glace en hurlant. Les parties étant très courtes, on est toujours tenté de réessayer une dernière fois. Allez, encore une. Non, vraiment, celle-ci c'est la dernière. Bon, vraiment, ce coup-ci j'arrête.

Un bon jeu pour tuer le temps qui, malgré des runs de moins de deux minutes, pourrait avaler tellement de vos secondes qu'un clic innocent sur le bouton jouer aura tôt fait d'escalader jusqu'au meurtre de masse - sans que personne ne vienne s'en plaindre. 24191743.review:
Grab your rapid-fire plasma gun, hop on the back of your futuristic motorcycle and prepare to hang on for dear life as you gun down the massive swarms headed your way.

Walter Machado has once again delivered a game (Free to play, no less!) that offers short, high-octane bursts of cyberpunk gun-toting action. With a soundtrack that has a similar heart-pounding vibe to UBERMOSH and UBERMOSH:BLACK, you'll definitely feel the adrenaline rush as you try and outlive the swarm as long as possible.

So far a very solid game that has its basic gameplay nailed right down and the graphics are a nice retro nod. My only criticisms is that there is some occasional slowdown when there's a lot going on and sometimes the clouds that form after you gun down enemies can obscure your vision, but that does very little to detract from the fun that this is.

I look forward to future content. Though as for some suggestions: Variety in the swarm would be nice, maybe some gun upgrades here and there and if there are gun upgrades, then maybe work in a version of the class mod system?

All in all, this is definitely a game worth playing. And if you like it, then I highly recommend buying UBERMOSH and UBERMOSH:BLACK and supporting Walter Machado with future projects.

24115633.review:
If you have played any games from the Ubermosh universe, this is a neat little extension on the background fluff, something that’s sorely missing from the series. On its own merit, this is still an excellent good coffee break distraction.

What you see in the trailer is the full game in its entirety. You ride a bike, shoot the swarm at best you could and delay the inevitable end for as long as possible. Each run will last around 1-3 minutes each, depending on how good or lucky you are. Trying to beat the best score would fill you with pure adrenalin every single time and getting the 4 achievements will make you break out a serious sweat.

That’s not to say the game is perfect though, for one I think the particle effects were too pervasive on the screen, I could hardly see where the swarm is half the time. The bullet spread is a bit of a hit-or-miss thing as well, making a lone bug much more dangerous than the pack where it derived from.

Lastly, I wish Steam leader board was implemented; it would have given me a better incentive to keep playing. Monster and weapon variation would have been nice too, but that’s probably out of the game’s original scope.

Looking for a quick game to play? You should look no further than this right here.

SWARMRIDERS - прикольный мини-экшен, а также относительно легкая + 1 "идеальная" игра.

Игра сделана как небольшой приквел к игре UBERMOSH:BLACK. Мы управляем байком, который несется сквозь темную долину, в безуспешной попытке убежать от своры монстров (этакого зерг-раша). Задача: продержаться как можно дольше, если хотите заработать все ачивки, и получить высшую оценку, то нужно продержаться пока таймер не отстучит 300. 

Байкер наш стреляет сам, так что на нас ложится движение, и направление стрельбы, управлять можно как с клавиатуры так и с геймпада, и на том и на том управление вполне удобное. 

Картинка в игре минималистичная, но приятная, музыка вполне создает драйвовую атмосферу.

Как итог: для бесплатной игры получился весьма интересный и приятный гибрид раннера с шутером.
8 байкеров из 10

Re Review time.

SWARMRIDERS endless shoot-em-up where all you do is move and infinite ammo and no button to shoot, just, shoot em up. There's not much to talk about but i do have some issues despite the fantastically fun gameplay and great art style, so let's start by the bad things. The game as simple as it is, it is somewhat difficult as you move on scoring higher times, and you take on swarms of endless hordes in a dark, black and white and badass enviroment. But there's one issue with the visuals that affect the gameplay, which is cool for your bike but really is annoying for the enemies, it is the full on fog by killing the enemies. I get it, to make it more difficult, but it is so much fog it literally is unfair and just not good and would be better if toned down a lot more or if just not there. Not only that but as you take on swarms and swarms of enemies, with a plasma gun and motor-byke, you'd expect to at least LOW DOWN the fog. As i'm writing this review i just can't stop thinking of its fantastic soundtrack which just seems like a remixed version of some of the tunes and music tracks from UBERMOSH as it is in the same universe so it does make sense, but it still is so fantastically badass and it makes the gameplay so much more fun. There isn't much on the game so the problems that there exist affect the gameplay, which is mainly the fog or the principle of moving around while you know it's not gonna work much as just going up and down from the far right of the screen is the way of survival. The fog still is constantly annoying though, as enemies can come from sides you never expect them from making it hard to even dodge enemies without getting damage from enemies you didn't know existed, while in Ubermosh you knew they existed and nearly all the time when you died it was your fault, not the game's fault. This is still though, a very good game, all i wished is that its fog was lowered down and better system for enemy spawning and then more content and this is surely a 10 but so far, it's the rating i'll show you soon enough only for its annoying fog and enemies spawning from bad places.

8.9/10 ~Fantastic game and some annoying design choices.

23713978.review:
[i]400 Years before the Blade Saint was even a glint on the cosmic horizon, the desert graveyard known as Ultakaar hungered. When the First Riders crossed those infested sands, they carelessly ignored the cracked bones jutting-out like bleached razors. The Swarms devoured them in endless waves of rabid abominations.

Those who survived refused to be mere cattle crawling over the great shifting maw. They launched into glistening work-out montages, injected pump-up music into their brains as they wrenched on rumbling jet-bikes, and made a sport of hunting the hunters, vowing to give the desert what it craved; fire, blood and oxide.[/i]

SWARMRIDERS is a flying dropkick to the face with its frenetic gameplay and eclectic metal tracks.

In a time when distracting us with hollow trailers that blast sh*tty dubstep noise at us is all the rage, game developer Walter Machado shows a rare display of confidence by telling us exactly what we're getting in the box. Through an Update Post and video accessible on the game's Store page, we get an honest look at what's offered. This is a stripped down game, distilled to its essential parts like a scrapyard goliath. (Well, maybe more like a cool Erector Set, it's a small free game after all.)

Desaturated, almost B&W pixel graphics give the game a raw vibe. Shocks of color accent important bits, like player health, bullets, and the enemies' glowing...optical...sensors? It could be their bungholes for all we know, all the more reason not to let them touch you.

Gritty Guy pilots a rocket-bike over a black desert while Tough Chick blasts at an endless horde of creeps with a purple laser shotgun. The longer you last, the more patches/achievements you collect. That's it, now you know the game. No power-ups and no do-overs in this twin-stick shooter. I imagine SWARMRIDERS would gobble all the quarters at an arcade, it's addicting, like licking peanut butter off a knife.

A mass of enemies tears ass towards your riders from the left side of the screen, enemies that flank to the top and bottom tend to coral you to the middle right side. It's possible to comfortably stay in that sweet spot early on, but eventually you'll be forced to put your reflexes to the test as you frantically weave around the increasing enemies, sometimes even charging directly into the oncoming horde, gasping for precious seconds of breathing room.

Lasting 150 seconds earns you all 4 patches and achievements, and while not impossible, it can definitely feel like it. Aiming with the mouse feels like the aiming reticle is cutting through a layer of molasses, you may need to externally twerk your mouse sensitivity because the game doesn't have any built-in options (other than "kill" or "die horribly" of course). However, it plays great with a gamepad, the controls are snappy.

Like Machado's previous UBERMOSH games, the music alone is worth giving these games a go. There's post-apoc surfer-metal, groovy cumbia-metal, and even a thrashing of booty-thumping cyber-metal, like something out of a Batman Beyond episode.

The "title track" is my favorite, it plays over the sketchy painting of our two protagonists blasting the gunk out those alien starfish creatures with the maybe buttfaces. It's a melanchololy tune that hints at a dark past and blazing future, which we know almost nothing about because there's very little lore shared by the developer. This game's intro screen gives us one sentence, explaining these events take place hundreds of years before the UBERMOSH games. The lore in those games is more enlightening, but even combined they only give us a few sentences.

I think this is to everyone's benefit though. This way the dev doesn't have to sweat an elaborate backstory, but through pixels and gameplay gives us enough dirt on this series to plant the seeds of our own crazy headcannon (like the slanty-lettered blurb at the top of this review). Walter Machado birthed one of the most fascinating universes in video game history, and he did it with only a handful of sentences! Your imagination will run wild fleshing out this 'verse and its characters, their schemes and motivations, their uncertain future.

Thank you, Walter, for this gift.

23698139.review:
A short, free game given as thanks to the UBERMOSH community, SWARMRIDERS is an endless runner type game mixed with a twin stick shooter and backed by a vaguely industrial soundtrack. Use WASD or the left control stick to move a bike around the screen, and right stick or mouse to aim your shots at swarms of flying robo squid thingies chasing after you.

I've yet to play any of the UBERMOSH games, so I've no idea how this ties into them at all since there's no explanation for anything, but then again, everything about the game is intentionally minimalist. There's only one enemy type, no form of upgrades or real progression, a pretty basic art style, and a handful of music tracks. It comes across not too dissimilar to a bonus stage between main levels of a bigger game, or at the very least like a neat little browser title, but I get the sense it really isn't trying to be anything more than that and is content to be a neat little distraction with some slight challenge, hence why it's being offered free.

It's entirely one-note in almost every way, and while that's not necessarily bad for what it sets out to be, it did end up leaving me wanting more, though not exactly in a good way. If anything, it mostly made me wish for additional features more so than actual content. As best I can tell, unless it was being completely masked by the music, there's no other sound effects in the game. That lack of audio feedback really hurts it and makes it feel devoid of a certain amount of pep and life that I think it would greatly benefit from, especially as I wasn't particularly into the music that it relies upon so heavily and I ended up muting the game after 10 or 15 minutes (sorry to all those that love it). Nor are there any kind of settings or options, so I couldn't do anything to address those issues either. It would have been nice to be able to turn off the cursor whilst playing with a control pad, but maybe that's just me and everyone else would be thankful to have it.

There are no additional modes to try or leaderboards to work through, or even a score to rack up, nothing to do other than last as long as you can and unlock a few achievements. Depending on their skill levels, some might do that their first try and get no more than a few minute's worth out of this, others might spend an hour or two on it and never get bored in the slightest during that time. I do really wish this was something greater with some substance that I could really sink my teeth into and play for hours, but as it is I mostly found it an adequate time-waster that has its charms but that you feel could go a whole lot further if it had just a little bit more.

23597808.review:
Be wary, this game is really addictive.
The basic concept is that you are in a futuristic motorbike with a laser machinegun and you are being chased by a swarm of things that will hurt you if they touch you.
You move with standard twin stick shooter controls and aim your machinegun to get rid of the enemy swarm. The action is really fast paced, and you need to keep a keen eye on the swarm, lest they overwhelm you.
When you die you get a score based on your survival time. The first 3 achievements are relatively easy to get, but the 4th one can be a bit of a pain in the rear.
Definitely recommended, even more so when you consider the price (it's free!)
Made by the same guy who made UBERMOSH.
